description: Skadi is the Norse goddess of winter, mountains, skiing, and hunting. A giantess by birth, she came to Asgard seeking vengeance for her father Thiazi's death and departed with a husband - Njord, the sea god, chosen by his beautiful feet. Their marriage failed due to incompatible natures: she could not bear the seagulls at his seaside home Noatun, and he could not endure the wolves howling at her mountain hall Thrymheim. Skadi represents the harsh, wild beauty of winter and the fierce independence of the mountain wilderness. The name 'Scandinavia' may derive from her name, marking her as a goddess of profound regional importance.

title: Skadi - Norse Goddess of Winter

sections.content: Skadi is the Norse goddess of winter, mountains, skiing, and hunting. A giantess (Jotun) by birth, daughter of the giant Thiazi, she came to Asgard fully armed demanding compensation for her father's death at the hands of the gods. Her fierce independence and warrior spirit impressed the Aesir, who offered her a husband from among them - but she had to choose by feet alone.
sections.title: Description

sections.content: When the gods killed Thiazi during the rescue of Idun and her golden apples, Skadi armed herself and marched to Asgard seeking revenge. The gods offered compensation: she could choose a husband from among them, but must select by looking only at their feet. Hoping to choose Baldr the Beautiful, she selected the most beautiful feet - which belonged to Njord, god of the sea. The gods also made her laugh, breaking her grim mood; Loki accomplished this by tying his beard to a goat in a crude tug-of-war.
sections.title: Coming to Asgard

sections.content: Skadi's marriage to Njord was doomed by their incompatible natures. She could not sleep at Noatun, his seaside home, kept awake by the crying of seagulls. He could not rest at Thrymheim, her mountain hall, disturbed by the howling of wolves. They agreed to spend nine nights at each home, but eventually separated. Some sources say Skadi later married Odin and bore him sons who became Swedish kings.
sections.title: The Failed Marriage

mythsAndLegends.title: The Vengeance of Skadi
mythsAndLegends.summary: When the gods killed her father Thiazi during the rescue of Idun, Skadi armed herself with helmet and mail and marched to Asgard demanding compensation. The gods offered weregild: she could choose a husband from among them, but must select only by their feet. She chose the most beautiful feet, hoping for Baldr, but they belonged to Njord.

mythsAndLegends.title: Loki Makes Skadi Laugh
mythsAndLegends.summary: Part of Skadi's compensation was that the gods must make her laugh. Loki accomplished this by tying one end of a rope to a goat and the other to his own beard, creating a crude tug-of-war that ended with Loki in Skadi's lap.

mythsAndLegends.title: The Failed Marriage
mythsAndLegends.summary: Skadi and Njord tried living nine nights at Thrymheim and nine at Noatun, but neither could tolerate the other's home. She hated the seagulls; he hated the wolves. They eventually separated, each returning to their native element.

mythsAndLegends.title: Skadi's Revenge on Loki
mythsAndLegends.summary: When the gods bound Loki for his crimes, it was Skadi who placed the venomous serpent above him, dripping poison on his face - perhaps remembering some slight, perhaps simply being an agent of divine punishment.
